snippet.textDisplay: I owned an 1983 Datsun/Nissan Sentra. I bought it used and I mean driven hard, family with young messy kids, alot of rough miles used but that thing just kept going and going. Now I wouldn't own a Nissan if I won it on The Price is Right.  I would be like, "Drew, I am going to pass that showcase to Susie!". The quality and reliability are gone and even if they could bring that back it would be years before I would take that chance and buy one. I don't think they will be around long enough for that.
snippet.textOriginal: I owned an 1983 Datsun/Nissan Sentra. I bought it used and I mean driven hard, family with young messy kids, alot of rough miles used but that thing just kept going and going. Now I wouldn't own a Nissan if I won it on The Price is Right.  I would be like, "Drew, I am going to pass that showcase to Susie!". The quality and reliability are gone and even if they could bring that back it would be years before I would take that chance and buy one. I don't think they will be around long enough for that.

snippet.textDisplay:
I don't think people are bored of GT-Rs, yes they don't upgrade it much, but what should they upgrade? Give it more power? They do that every few years (2010, 2012, 2013, 2017), 2 were minor, 2 were bigger. And if you want more power you have many aftermarket options. Facelift? Also did that in 2011 and 2017 and they can't change too much because of the attention they put into aerodynamics in the first place. They introduced Nismo GT-R in 2015. Change the engine? That's out of the question. Suspension is amazing by itself and if you have to upgrade there are options for that too. Basically it's a car that's amazing out of the box and you have tons of options to modify it (although it's pretty damn expensive), people don't get bored of that so easily. If they make it slightly better no one will care, if they make it a lot better they have to raise the price accordingly and I'd prefer the price to stay the same for the base model.

I agree on S16, I'd love to see that and maybe buy it when I pay off my R35.

To be fair I mostly care about older cars (and same goes for most of my friends), BMW ended with the E chassis for me, Toyota only has a GT-86, Mitsubishi ended with Evo 9, Subaru has BRZ and kinda WRX (I much prefer older ones), Mazda has a Miata, Honda ended with S2000, Nissan still has R35 GT-R and 370z. There are some new supercars I like, but I can't afford them, so from the past 5 years the only cars I've liked and could buy were Miata, BRZ/GT-86, 370z and R35 GT-R, if you stretch it to past 10 years the only additions are E92 and E60 Ms and S2000.


Also I have GT-R logo tattoo and I wasn't even paid!

snippet.textDisplay:
They laid an egg with their updated Leaf. The first gen Leaf was cute and quirky. But the second gen was just a rehash of the same technologies with an uglier exterior. Yes, it got 50 miles more per full charge, but otherwise it was the same car with the same dated interior.
If they stopped worrying about the Maxima, they could focus on improving their EV lineup. They already have the chassis manufacturing in place, they could create EV versions of the Altima and Sentra too. Not to mention pulling an NSX and putting EV motors into the GTR.
snippet.textOriginal:
They laid an egg with their updated Leaf. The first gen Leaf was cute and quirky. But the second gen was just a rehash of the same technologies with an uglier exterior. Yes, it got 50 miles more per full charge, but otherwise it was the same car with the same dated interior. 
If they stopped worrying about the Maxima, they could focus on improving their EV lineup. They already have the chassis manufacturing in place, they could create EV versions of the Altima and Sentra too. Not to mention pulling an NSX and putting EV motors into the GTR.

snippet.textDisplay: Before Nissan can revamp it's sports cars, it has to work from the bottom up. Sports cars are not money makers, the bread and butter lines which bring in the cash for R&D are a priority, once your cash flow improves, then you can tackle niche lines (GTR and Z.)

snippet.textDisplay: Personally, i am happy with my '17 370. But i will say that there are things that annoy me, at 14.5k miles i already have a creaky and rattley interior. I cant open my hatch from inside the car and nobody can figure it out on their own.... somehow?.. that being said, it does drive great, im happy with the power from stock and it does make me feel special knowing im one of the few in my city that own a manual Z car or that even owns one of the last manual RWD 2 door sports cars with hydraulic power steering in production currently. It will be interesting to see if Nissan (or any other manufacturer) will come out of this produce cheap, sell cheap and we slap into a new car in about a year or two mentality that caters to the welfare moms of the US...

snippet.textDisplay:
When I worked for Toyota in sales back in 2010, I had a customer bring in a Murano to trade for a Camry. Murano was only 3 years old, and he and his wife were eager to trade it in...like, a little TOO eager to trade it in.
They owed $11,000 on it still and trade in price was about $9,000. We were really close to making a deal, but my manager and I were skeptical about the deal. Something seemed a little off about this couple, and we knew they were hiding something...we ran a Car Fax and it was clean, but Nissan had a history of bad CVT transmissions. We talked out back about doing the deal or not, and decided NO, we didn't really want the trade in, so we weren't going to overpay for a deal.
I went back to customers and told them we were sticking to $9,000 for the Murano. They left the dealership mad that we weren't about to pay more for their Murano. A few weeks later, I was talking to a buddy of mine that worked sales at another Toyota store a few cities away...he told me about a deal they did on a Murano for a couple that told him they were dealing with our store, but couldn't make the deal happen. That dealership would discover that the Murano's transmission was pooched...well, no problem, it's sill under warranty, so we'll just get Nissan to drop in a new one, right?...nope!
Turns out, it had gone through 5 transmissions in 3 years under warranty and Nissan wouldn't pay for another one, even though they have a 10 yr warranty.
The dealership now had to fork out $5,000 on top of the $11,000 they put into it, making it now cost $16,000. They eventually sold it for $12,000 and took a loss of $4,000....sometimes, the best deals you make, are the ones you don't make! And if you find yourself in a Nissan dealership, thinking about getting that new Murano....RUN!!
snippet.textOriginal:
When I worked for Toyota in sales back in 2010, I had a customer bring in a Murano to trade for a Camry. Murano was only 3 years old, and he and his wife were eager to trade it in...like, a little TOO eager to trade it in. 
    They owed $11,000 on it still and trade in price was about $9,000.  We were really close to making a deal, but my manager and I were skeptical about the deal. Something seemed a little off about this couple, and we knew they were hiding something...we ran a Car Fax and it was clean, but Nissan had a history of bad CVT transmissions. We talked out back about doing the deal or not, and decided NO, we didn't really want the trade in, so we weren't going to overpay for a deal. 
    I went back to customers and told them we were sticking to $9,000 for the Murano. They left the dealership mad that we weren't about to pay more for their Murano. A few weeks later, I was talking to a buddy of mine that worked sales at another Toyota store a few cities away...he told me about a deal they did on a Murano for a couple that told him they were dealing with our store, but couldn't make the deal happen. That dealership would discover that the Murano's transmission was pooched...well, no problem, it's sill under warranty, so we'll just get Nissan to drop in a new one, right?...nope! 
        Turns out, it had gone through 5 transmissions in 3 years under warranty and Nissan wouldn't pay for another one, even though they have a 10 yr warranty. 
    The dealership now had to fork out $5,000 on top of the $11,000 they put into it, making it now cost $16,000. They eventually sold it for $12,000 and took a loss of $4,000....sometimes, the best deals you make, are the ones you don't make! And if you find yourself in a Nissan dealership, thinking about getting that new Murano....RUN!!

snippet.textDisplay:
They don't need to improve the GTR. They completely fucked themselves by making an ugly ass car that cost 90k. They need to bring back the boutique style of performance and function.

Right now it's all about LED's , high price tags, and bullshit auto gear boxes.

If they made a streamlined Skyline GTR that mimicked the trend of the R32,33,34 then they would have built an amazing seller. It wouldn't look like a hatchback, and cost more than a 5 series BMW. It would be 40-50k and have 4 seats and a beautifully machined 6 speed manual transmission. It would be a car for the fans, not a car for metrosexual business executives.

A new care every few years? Are you fucking joking? That's not how you make a business work. That's how you go bankrupt. The Tacoma with the 1GRFE is one of the best pickup trucks of this century. It ran for 10 years. Nissan needs to go back to the drawing board, and ignore hyped up complainers like this host.
snippet.textOriginal:

It would be 40-50k and have 4 seats and a beautifully machined 6 speed manual transmission. It would be a car for the fans, not a car for metrosexual business executives.

snippet.textDisplay: My first car was a Datsun 2000, my dad had a 240z. I currently have an Infiniti M45 I bought a dozen years ago. I'd consider a new Infiniti, but damn. From the idiotic naming (everything is a Q?) from something that made sense, to fugly weird flame styling and cheap-ass interiors, they lost me. BTW, throwing timing belts is how most Datsun 1600's and 2000's died. How about a new version of the Datsun 210? BMW hasn't managed a 2002 update.
snippet.textOriginal: My first car was a Datsun 2000, my dad had a 240z. I currently have an Infiniti M45 I bought a dozen years ago. I'd consider a new Infiniti, but damn. From the idiotic naming (everything is a Q?) from something that made sense, to fugly weird flame styling and cheap-ass interiors, they lost me. BTW, throwing timing belts is how most Datsun 1600's and 2000's died. How about a new version of the *Datsun 210?* BMW hasn't managed a 2002 update.

snippet.textDisplay: I work for Nissan as a mechanic and the reasoning behind it was I loved there old cars and decided if I would specialize in one make I might as well do my favorite, and I must say this video is totally spot on, The 2020 line up? Can’t tell the difference between a Rogue sport or a Kicks, can’t tell the difference from a Altima or Maxima or even versa now! If I ever get a work order and it is older than a 2005 I can find that car instantly! but if it’s a 2019 or 2020 they look exactly the same to me, I mean the frontier hasn’t been updated in 16 years. The maximas and the Rogues i don’t see much problems with there CVTS but that doesn’t mean I never do. They need to pull there heads out of there asses and up the quality and stand out from all of the other commuter cars and bring back cool cars that are affordable like the SE-R line.

snippet.textDisplay:
Get rid of:
The Leaf;
The Note;
The Maxima;
The Juke;
The Qashqai;
Change the Pulsar;
Bring back the manual and inline-6;
Revive the GT-R name and keep purity, it being manual with a clutch, AWD and revive the RB;

Encourage drift culture more and remember where they started and why they became successful;

Rise above the cross-over and forget about it. Scrap the idea;
Please, Nissan, don't die and become of the now bland and mainstream automotive bore that of today. Bring back what we want. The Yen (¥) talks, and so do we.
All Japanese companys need to go back to what they were doing in the 90s and their high proformance cars are not affordable anymore.

snippet.textDisplay:
Titan 💩 XD,
29,000 miles.... What's been fixed?
6 alignments, needs a 7th.
New tires
Transfer case broke and has been replaced.
New steering box & pitman arm.
Seat heaters replaced X2.
Tail lights and 3rd brake light replaced due to factory defects.
ECM & TCM retuned multiple times for hard shifting and dead pedal.
Wind noise (some owners have had the door handle covers fall off and door trim peel off)
Radio head units flash randomly or reboot.

This thing is a 💩.
snippet.textOriginal:
Titan 💩 XD,
29,000 miles.... What's been fixed?
6 alignments, needs a 7th. 
New tires
Transfer case broke and has been replaced. 
New steering box & pitman arm. 
Seat heaters replaced X2. 
Tail lights and 3rd brake light replaced due to factory defects. 
ECM & TCM retuned multiple times for hard shifting and dead pedal. 
Wind noise (some owners have had the door handle covers fall off and door trim peel off)
Radio head units flash randomly or reboot. 

This thing is a 💩.

snippet.textDisplay:
They're just LAZY...
GT-R is great, but basically the same car since 2007, they just did minor update every few years. (and the newer model ), it used to be 70k car, but now it's 120-140k car, while sales number keep dropping, as if they're trying to milk a dead horse 😑
370Z and nissan juke also stuck with the same design for a decade.
They did release all-new Livina, which basically just a Mitsubishi Xpander with body kit.
Datsun (nissan sub-brand) also dying in many countries.

My only suggestion is they should update GT-R design (something like GTR50 looks great)
and bring down the price to its original 60k-70k, so it could compete with 2020 Chevrolet Corvette C8

snippet.textDisplay: I feel the problem is the range of cars that Nissan make needs adjusting/rethinking. What we need is a Pulsar hatchback to rvial say the VW Golf, and make a made AWD GTiR version. The R35 GTR is awesome but they needed to have done what they did with the Skylines and made a range of cars. They put all of their eggs in one basket for the R35 and proved it was great, but at the cost of it being out of reach to a lot of people. If there was say a GTST version or a GTT, that would have got that chassis used more. The 350/370 are ok, they fill that two seater option in the range but need updating. The whole Juke, Qashqai, X-Trail etc needs to be reduced to one crossover and one large one like the PathFinder. I changed from an R33 GTR to a MK5 GTi due to budget and was gutted that Nissan doesnt do a hot hatch. I've now changed into a MK7 Golf R, as there's nothing in the Nissan line up that covers AWD, decent automatic, hot hatch etc. They due a sluggy CVT Juke Nismo which is mundane at best. Come on Nissan, you can do this! 🙌🏻
snippet.textOriginal: I feel the problem is the range of cars that Nissan make needs adjusting/rethinking. They put all of their eggs in one basket for the R35 and proved it was great, but at the cost of it being out of reach to a lot of people. If there was say a GTST version or a GTT, that would have got that chassis used more. The 350/370 are ok, they fill that two seater option in the range but need updating. The whole Juke, Qashqai, X-Trail etc needs to be reduced to one crossover and one large one like the PathFinder. I changed from an R33 GTR to a MK5 GTi due to budget and was gutted that Nissan doesnt do a hot hatch. I've now changed into a MK7 Golf R, as there's nothing in the Nissan line up that covers AWD, decent automatic, hot hatch etc. They due a sluggy CVT Juke Nismo which is mundane at best. Come on Nissan, you can do this! 🙌🏻

snippet.textDisplay:
One thing I would love to see Nissan do is give the GTR back its identity. I'm never going to own one, old and new ones are just to much money, but what made me fall in love with the old Skylines was their unusual look. They were the ultimate factory sleeper. Stock, they looked like any other sporty coupe. Something the divorced single mom might dive. If you saw one on the street and you didn't know what you were looking at you would never know the monster that lived under that unsuspecting skin. The all wheel drive, four wheel steering and straight six that with some tinkering could blow up most V8s of the era.


Now, it just looks like any other sports car. Sure it's still the monster it always was but it's lost its mystique. It's lost its identity. It's not the ultimate muscle car sleeper that can actually handle a corner, it's just another Japanese sports car trying to compete with the Porsches and Ferraris and not quite understanding what makes those cars desirable.
snippet.textOriginal:
One  thing I would love to see Nissan do is give the GTR back its identity. I'm never going to own one, old and new ones are just to much money, but what made me fall in love with the old Skylines was their unusual look. They were the ultimate factory sleeper. Stock, they looked like any other sporty coupe. Something the divorced single mom might dive. If you saw one on the street and you didn't know what you were looking at you would never know the monster that lived under that unsuspecting skin. The all wheel drive, four wheel steering and straight six that with some tinkering could blow up most V8s of the era.


Now, it just looks like any other sports car. Sure it's still the monster it always was but it's lost its mystique. It's lost its identity. It's not the ultimate muscle car sleeper that can actually handle a corner, it's just another Japanese sports car trying to compete with the Porsches and Ferraris and not quite understanding what makes those cars desirable.

snippet.textDisplay: He seems to be very biased towards the sports cars, which people aren't really buying anymore. Seems like they need to focus on their bread and butter cars and make them better. Sorry but focusing on the Z and GT-R isn't going to help Nissan when everyone is buying crossovers. Think about it, most competitors best selling models are indeed crossovers. Seems like they should focus on the Rogue, Pathfinder, get profit off of those, then focus on Sedans, then focus on sports cars.

snippet.textDisplay: Despite all their failures, one of my favorite cars were built by Nissan, the GTR R-34! I also owned a Nissan Frontier 2003 and that truck despite it being slow and way WAY underpowered for me, it was tough, and fun to drive especially in the rain! Used to go out and find corners to drift with it lol 😂 I looked forward to those rainy days, right up until I wrecked it, and no it wasn’t my fault it happened, believe it or not the accident happened when I was being a responsible driver imagine that 😂
snippet.textOriginal: Despite all their failures, one of my favorite cars were built by Nissan, the GTR R-34! I also owned a Nissan Frontier 2003 and that truck despite it being slow and way WAY underpowered for me, it was tough, and fun to drive especially in the rain! Used to go out and find corners to drift with it lol 😂 I looked forward to those rainy days, right up until I wrecked it, and no it wasn’t my fault it happened, believe it or not the accident happened when I was being a responsible driver imagine that 😂

snippet.textDisplay: I've driven Nissans for a very long time. My 2000 Altima was built like a truck. The shift linkage and drive train was solid, the engine was torqy and balanced. Then I began to drive tons of their newer rentals. And the only thing I liked about them was the fuel capacity of the new Altima. Everything else felt like it was some unhappy employee's begrudged homework. It felt crappy and, like you said, incredibly uninspired. In addition to that everything felt chintzy, like it's about to fall apart, and this was far more present on the Sentras. Nissan used to build good stuff. It's a shame they're all garbage now. Uninspired design, tired old GT-Rs (which should have a freaking MANUAL option) and generally just cookie-cutter yawn-factories. Thanks for the video, Nolan and Donut!
snippet.textOriginal: I've driven Nissans for a very long time. My 2000 Altima was built like a truck. The shift linkage and drive train was solid, the engine was torqy and balanced. Then I began to drive tons of their newer rentals. And the only thing I liked about them was the fuel capacity of the new Altima. Everything else felt like it was some unhappy employee's begrudged homework. It felt crappy and, like you said, incredibly uninspired. In addition to that everything felt chintzy, like it's about to fall apart, and this was far more present on the Sentras. Nissan used to build good stuff. It's a shame they're all garbage now. Uninspired design, tired old GT-Rs (which should have a freaking MANUAL option) and generally just cookie-cutter yawn-factories. Thanks for the video, Nolan and Donut!

snippet.textDisplay: I owned a few Datsuns.. great cars..indestructible.   Nissan problems stated when they merged with Renault/Mitsubishi.   Every Mitsubishi I ever owned was plagued by electrical problems.   The Nissan Frontier mid-size truck has the lowest owner satisfaction rating,  one of the few pickups that loses over 50% of it's value after 1 year.

snippet.textDisplay: My dad owned a '71 Datsun 510 (Bluebird, I think, in other markets) and that was a fantastic little car.  Fun to drive, well designed and engineered, surprisingly robust.  That was the first car I ever drove.  Did I mention that it was also attractive?  It looked like a smaller GC-10 Skyline and had an engine that was basically like that in a 240Z with two cylinders removed.  That was when Nissan was good, in my opinion.  Now, they're paired with fecking Renault, and the results match my predictions from when it happened.
snippet.textOriginal: My dad owned a '71 Datsun 510 (Bluebird, I think, in other markets) and that was a fantastic little car.  Fun to drive, well designed and engineered, surprisingly robust.  That was the first car I ever drove.  Did I mention that it was also attractive?  It looked like a smaller GC-10 Skyline and had an engine that was basically like that in a 240Z with two cylinders removed.  That was when Nissan was good, in my opinion.  Now, they're paired with fecking Renault, and the results match my predictions from when it happened.
